author: By Bernard Mokam and Rachel Nostrant
title: Small Earthquake Rumbles in Los Angeles Area
description: The authorities said there were no initial reports of damage from the quake, which struck in the hills west of Malibu.
content: Residents of parts of Los Angeles County felt a minor earthquake centered west of Malibu, Calif., on Sunday afternoon. Preliminary estimates showed that the quake had a magnitude of 4.1, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: New Deal Reached to End Wildcat Strikes by N.Y. Prison Guards
description: The state and the correctional officers’ union agreed that officers should return to work Monday and that some provisions of a solitary confinement law would be put on pause.
content: A new agreement has been reached to end wildcat strikes by thousands of New York State correctional officers, which have created chaos throughout the prison system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: A Hollywood Star With a Secret That Could Have Ended Her Career
description: Merle Oberon was a popular actress who was once nominated for an Oscar. But a fact that she hid from the public threatened to unspool her entire life’s work.
content: The Academy Awards always bring with them a series of firsts. First Black man to win for best costume design (Paul Tazewell). First openly trans person to be nominated for an Oscar (Karla Sofía Gascón). First Latvian film to win an Oscar (“Flow”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: There Is a Liberal Answer to the Trump-Musk Wrecking Ball
description: Right-wing populism thrives on scarcity. The answer is abundance. But a politics of abundance will work only if Democrats confront where their approach has failed.
content: I keep seeing Democrats say the resistance failed. On these pages, James Carville counseled Democrats to “roll over and play dead” until the Trump administration collapses beneath its own weight. Assuming corpse pose, Carville said, would be “a wiser approach than we pursued in the first Trump administration, when Democrats tried and failed at the art of resistance politics.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Syria’s Interim President Calls for Unity Amid Fresh Fighting
description: More than 1,000 people have been killed in clashes in the coastal provinces of Syria, according to one war monitoring group.
content: Syria’s interim president, Ahmed al-Shara, appealed on Sunday for calm and for unity as he moved to reassure the nation after days of clashes that a monitoring group said had killed hundreds of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger and Reid J. Epstein
title: MeidasTouch Pops on Podcast Charts as Progressives Search for Answers
description: The company is a leader among numerous digital-first outlets that have been reshaping the progressive media landscape since President Trump took office.
content: Soon after the recent contentious Oval Office meeting between President Trump and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, Senator Adam Schiff went on camera to offer his assessment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: A Political Reporter Takes Her Scoops to YouTube
description: Most online political media stars traffic in highly partisan viewpoints. Tara Palmeri hopes that playing it straight will pay off.
content: After a few years of writing what she called a “niche newsletter for Washington insiders,” the political journalist Tara Palmeri decided she wanted to reach a wider audience. A much wider audience.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Started a Conversation With a Woman Sitting to My Right’
description: Seats up close for a Broadway show, a friendly question on the 7 and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Are Liberal Democrats Really ‘Bewildered’?
description: Readers respond to a column by Nicholas Kristof about his “Bewildered Liberals Book Club.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Miriam Jordan
title: A Chill Sets In for Undocumented Workers, and Those Who Hire Them
description: Fearing roundups, many immigrants are staying home. Construction, agriculture, senior care and hospitality employers say labor shortages will worsen.
content: The railroad tracks that slice through downtown Freehold, N.J., used to be lined by dozens of men, waiting for work. Each morning, the men — day laborers, almost all from Latin America and undocumented — would be scooped up by local contractors in pickup trucks for jobs painting, landscaping, removing debris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Geoff Nicholson, Author of Darkly Comic Novels, Dies at 71
description: In more than a dozen books, he created characters who were obsessed with maps, urban walking, sexual fetishes and Volkswagen Beetles.
content: Geoff Nicholson, whose darkly comic literary novels and eclectic nonfiction were full of characters defined by their obsessions — with cartography, Volkswagen Beetles, urban walking, jokes and sexual fetishes, many of which were enduring interests of Mr. Nicholson himself — died on Jan. 18 in Colchester, England, northeast of London. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: The Oscar-Winning Movie That Pets Can’t Stop Watching
description: “Flow,” a dialogue-free animated Latvian film made with open-source software, is keeping our domesticated friends riveted.
content: One night shortly before the Oscars ceremony, my boyfriend decided to catch up on “Flow,” the animated film from Latvia that would go on to win best animated feature. When I returned home from dinner, I found that the film had also captured the attention of another viewer — my dog Daisy, a corgi mix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Weber
title: Athol Fugard, South African Playwright Who Dissected Apartheid, Dies at 92
description: In works that included “Blood Knot,” “Sizwe Banzi Is Dead” and “The Island,” he exposed the realities of racial separatism in his homeland.
content: Athol Fugard, the South African playwright whose portrayals of intimate relationships burdened by oppressive racial separatism exposed the cruel psychological torment of apartheid to an international audience, died on Saturday night at his home in Stellenbosch, a town near Cape Town. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Berlinger
title: Is the Giant Sneaker Trend Over?
description: Bigger, bulkier sneakers have dominated the fashion landscape, but designers are moving toward a sleeker peekaboo style.
content: After years of the ever bigger, ever bulkier sneaker, there seems to be bit of a backlash: Sneakers have become sleek, streamlined and, in a word, skinny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: David Sellers, Father of the Design-Build Movement, Dies at 86
description: He believed that architects could design better buildings if they did the construction themselves. His do-it-yourself approach caught on.
content: David Sellers, a maverick architect who helped start a movement based on the radical idea that structures turned out better if they were built by the people who had designed them, died on Feb. 9 in Los Angeles. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: Democrats Voice Regret on Scattered Responses to Trump’s Speech
description: Progressive and moderate Democrats criticized a protest by Representative Al Green as a distraction, and the party leadership tried to refocus attention on economic issues.
content: Democratic lawmakers on Sunday expressed disappointment at their party’s uncoordinated response to President Trump’s address to Congress last week, criticizing a colleague who staged a one-man protest during the speech by standing up and repeatedly shouting, “No mandate.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: For These Women, It’s Kill or Be Killed
description: Our critic on Deanna Raybourn’s “Kills Well With Others” and three more new books.
content: In Raybourn’s “Killers of a Certain Age” (2022), four female assassins on a celebratory retirement cruise discovered their lives were in danger. It was a fresh and fun adventure with a steel-toed kick. Now the quartet returns in the equally delightful KILLS WELL WITH OTHERS (Berkley, 356 pp., $29).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Flo Fox, 79, Dies; Street Photographer Overcame Blindness and Paralysis
description: She was legally blind and used a motorized wheelchair, but she managed to capture what she called the “ironic reality” of New York City on film.
content: Flo Fox, an indomitable photographer who was born blind in one eye and who later lost her vision in the other from multiple sclerosis — which eventually paralyzed her from the neck down — but who never stopped shooting what she called the “ironic reality” of New York’s streetscape, died on March 2 at her home in Manhattan. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 9, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 9, 2025.
content: An article on Page 22 this weekend about the film director Bong Joon Ho misstated the number of feature films Bong Joon Ho has made. “Mickey 17” is his eighth, not his seventh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Reham Mourshed
title: Chaos Sweeps Coastal Syria: ‘We Have to Get Out of Here’
description: Residents described shootings outside their homes and bodies in the streets in Syria’s worst unrest since Bashar al-Assad’s ouster. More than 1,000 people have been killed since Thursday, a war monitor said.
content: The gunfire began at dawn on Friday in the town of al-Haffa on Syria’s Mediterranean coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: The Joy and Pain of Three Female Friends
description: On “The White Lotus,” a friendship triangle is hitting home with viewers.
content: As Desiree Frederickson, 40, started watching the third season of “The White Lotus,” the show quickly became personal for her. “I was immediately triggered,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanna Drusin
title: Want to Teach With Our Contests? Ask Your School Librarian for Help.
description: Here’s how a team of librarians collaborated with teachers to help students enter our Open Letters Contest — and to create their school’s own competition.
content: This teaching idea was submitted by Joanna Drusin, a librarian at Brooklyn Technical High School in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: High Prices Hit a French Classic: Beef Bourguignon
description: Businesses across Europe, including restaurants in Paris that make the dish, are being squeezed by sticky inflation.
content: At Le Bouillon Chartier in Paris, the recipe for a perfect beef Bourguignon involves beef, carrots, wine, butter and “coquillettes,” a tiny macaroni-shaped pasta. It is cooked for at least three hours. And it must be affordable, so the price cannot be more than 10 euros a dish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir A. Desai
title: Musk’s Tweet-Fueled Bubble May Be About to Burst
description: His greatest achievement is building a financial cult that serves as the engine for his enormous wealth.
content: Elon Musk’s business empire may be starting to wobble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Orovic
title: Echoing a Roman Emperor, Croatia Tries to Cap Soaring Prices
description: Diocletian, who once ruled territory that now includes Croatia, tried and failed to rein in inflation by dictating prices. Today’s government hopes its own such plan will succeed.
content: In 301 A.D., the Emperor Diocletian made a bold but ultimately unsuccessful bid to address the inflation that was rampaging across the eastern half of the divided Roman Empire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Immigration Authorities Arrest Pro-Palestinian Activist at Columbia
description: Mahmoud Khalil, who recently completed a graduate program at Columbia, has legal permanent residency, his lawyer said.
content: Federal immigration authorities on Saturday detained a well-known activist who played a major role in Columbia University’s pro-Palestinian student movement last year, his lawyer said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: A Nanny on the Run With Someone Else’s Daughter
description: “The Tokyo Suite” explores class divisions in contemporary Brazil via the twinned stories of a high-powered TV executive and the desperate caretaker of her child.
content: Humanity is hurtling into outer space, creating new states of matter and developing ever-creepier forms of artificial intelligence — one of which I consulted to help compose this sentence — and yet still hasn’t solved child care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Radical Pleasure of Fashion That Makes You Feel
description: Comme des Garçons, Rick Owens, and Undercover embrace the power of human scale.
content: It’s not often that fashion show notes, the word salads that purport to explain the idea behind a collection but often seem like a pointless justification, offer a gut punch of surprise. But that’s what happened after the Comme des Garçons show, when Rei Kawakubo issued her usual explanatory aphorism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,360
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, March 10, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nostrant
title: Tribes and Students Sue Trump Administration Over Firings at Native Schools
description: More than one quarter of the staff members at the only two federally run colleges for Native students were cut in February.
content: A group of Native American tribes and students is suing the Trump administration to reverse its recent firing of federal workers at Native schools that they said has severely lowered their quality of education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan and Tim Balk
title: Rage Against Elon Musk Turns Tesla Into a Target
description: The backlash against the electric vehicle company has turned violent at times, as its billionaire chief executive parlays his support for President Trump into consequential influence over the federal government.
content: Tesla charging stations were set ablaze near Boston on Monday. Shots were fired at a Tesla dealership in Oregon after midnight on Thursday. Arrests were made at a nonviolent protest at a Tesla dealership in Lower Manhattan on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Renée Bergland
title: What the Dodo Tells Us, 300 Years After Its Extinction
description: The dodo is both a victim of humans and a symbol of our own power, carelessness and avarice.
content: Extinction troubled us long before we had a name for it. The original mascot for the loss of species, even before the concept was understood, was the dodo. The bird — fat and flightless, found by 17th-century European sailors on the island of Mauritius — fell victim to one of the earliest known extinctions caused by Western humans. For four centuries, it’s been a symbol in our art and arguments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: Classics Just Twisted Enough to Wear
description: A little adjustment on a familiar garment can go a long way.
content: Hang around the fashion industry for all of, oh, five minutes, and you’ll start to hear the term “classics with a twist.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Arkansas Man Sentenced to 8 Years for Producing Deadly Ricin Poison
description: Jason Kale Clampit, 44, was sentenced for possession of ricin, which he had made to set traps for trespassers, prosecutors said.
content: An Arkansas man who produced jars of the lethal poison ricin on his property with the intention of setting traps for trespassers was sentenced to eight years in prison for possessing a biological agent, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Fred Stolle, Golden-Age Australian Tennis Star, Dies at 86
description: In addition to winning 19 Grand Slam titles, including two singles championships, he was a coach, a club pro and a television commentator.
content: Fred Stolle, a popular Hall of Fame Australian tennis player who won 19 Grand Slam titles, including two singles championships, during a golden age for his countrymen internationally, died on March 5 at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: How Would Peacekeeping Work in Ukraine? These Experts Gamed It Out.
description: The publication of the detailed analysis was a sign that a cease-fire has gone from a theoretical exercise to an urgent and practical issue.
content: When military and civilian experts on peacekeeping started meeting in Geneva in the spring of 2022, they insisted on discretion. Their topic was sensitive: how to implement a future cease-fire in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Israeli Energy Minister Cuts Off Electricity to Gaza
description: The move, which will mainly affect a single wastewater treatment plant, appeared intended to put pressure on Hamas.
content: Israel’s energy minister said on Sunday that he was immediately cutting off electricity to the Gaza Strip, a move that may have limited impact in Gaza, given restrictions already in place, but that comes as Israel tries to pressure Hamas amid talks over their fragile truce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Joey Molland, of the Power-Pop Band Badfinger, Dies at 77
description: He was the last remaining core member of a group that was both propelled and pigeonholed in the 1970s by its close association with the Beatles.
content: Joey Molland, a guitarist and songwriter who was the last surviving member of Badfinger, one of the first acts signed to the Beatles’ Apple Records and a power-pop force in the early 1970s on the strength of hits like “Day After Day” and “No Matter What,” died on March 1 in St. Louis Park, Minn. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The MAGA Culture War Comes for Georgetown Law
description: If our liberties can survive a world war, then they can and should survive the Trump administration.
content: This might sound like a funny thing to say, but I’ve rarely read a more unconstitutional letter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: As Utility Bills Soar, New Yorkers Face the Cost of a Greener Future
description: The utility that serves New York City and Westchester County has filed a request to raise its rates to help pay for the shift to cleaner energy, sparking dismay among residents.
content: When New Yorkers get a sky-high energy bill, many turn to social media and vent their frustrations on Instagram, TikTok or Reddit. Recently, their rage has been directed toward a state-run website, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Trump Casts a Long Shadow Over a Governor’s Race
description: President Trump and his divisive policies are helping to define the primary races for New Jersey governor.
content: There are plenty of thorny policy issues facing the next governor of New Jersey. Housing and health care costs are high. Mass transit is on the ropes. Schools are among the most segregated in the country, and sea levels along the state’s 130-mile coastline are rising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Oppenheimer, Robert Fass, Tally Abecassis, Tanya Pérez, John Woo, Aaron Esposito, Sophia Lanman and Devin Murphy
title: The Sunday Read: ‘How I Learned That the Problem in My Marriage Was Me’
description: It took a superstar couples therapist to help me see beyond my anger.
content: One thing I’ve learned from being married to my wife, Jess, who is a couples therapist, is how vast the distance is between the masks people show to the world and the messy realities that live behind them. Every couple knows its own drama, but we still fall prey to the illusion that all other couples have seamlessly satisfying relationships. The truth about marriage — including my own — is that even the most functional couples are merely doing the best they can with the lives that have been bestowed on them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Anderson
title: What I Found on the 365-Mile Trail of a Lost Folk Hero
description: The Old Leatherman, a sort of real-life Northeastern Sasquatch, g​ave me an excuse to step outside my own life.
content: Sometime in the 1850s or ’60s, at a terrible moment in U.S. history, a strange man seemed to sprout, out of nowhere, into the rocky landscape between New York City and Hartford. The word “strange” hardly captures his strangeness. He was rough and hairy, and he wandered around on back roads, sleeping in caves. Above all, he refused to explain himself. As one newspaper put it: “He is a mystery, and a very greasy and ill-odored one.” Other papers referred to him as “the animal” or (just throwing up their hands) “this uncouth and unkempt ‘What is it?’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Art Schallock, Oldest Surviving Major Leaguer, Dies at 100
description: A pitcher, he played for the Yankees and the Orioles. When Mickey Mantle was sent to the minors in 1951, Schallock was called up.
content: Art Schallock, the New York Yankees and Baltimore Orioles left-handed pitcher of the 1950s who had been the oldest living former major leaguer, died on Thursday in Sonoma, Calif. He was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Imagines an Oval Office Meeting With Trump, Rubio and Musk
description: This week, the opener described a conflict between Elon Musk and Marco Rubio. Lady Gaga proved to be a capable joke-teller as both the host and the musical guest.
content: Following a report in The New York Times about a White House meeting where Elon Musk and Secretary of State Marco Rubio had clashed in front of President Trump, it was up to “Saturday Night Live” to imagine how they might make peace — and to let us listen in on their inner monologues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and David W. Chen
title: State Republicans Eager to Climb on Cost-Cutting Bandwagon
description: G.O.P. governors and legislators are parroting the federal Department of Government Efficiency by creating panels at the state level. But the similarities only go so far.
content: Clamoring to capitalize on the MAGA base’s excitement over Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency, Republican officials in more than a dozen states have moved to start their own versions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyona Synenko
title: How I Lost Hope and Took Up Singing
description: When there is so much uncertainty about the shape of the future, the only time to do things is now.
content: Earlier this winter I was sitting with my friend Sasha in his Soviet-era apartment building in our hometown, Odesa, on the Black Sea coast of Ukraine. He told me about an airstrike that had shattered a few of his neighbors’ windows. Frowning as he told the story, he then turned his chair to face his electric piano. As the crease across his forehead eased, he said, “But our little song is not over yet.” He used the phrase in its metaphorical “not everything is lost” meaning and quite literally — I had come to his austere bachelor flat for singing class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 638
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, March 10, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Hamburg Airport Halts All Flights as Ground Staff Strike
description: The airport in Germany’s second largest city said the one-day strike, called over pay and conditions, began earlier than expected “without any notice.”
content: The airport in Hamburg, Germany’s second largest city, said it had canceled all flights on Sunday because of a one-day strike over pay by ground staff called by a labor union that started its action earlier than expected with little warning.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trend Overload
description: We cover a surprising form of Gen Z burnout.
content: Consider yourself lucky if you have never heard of the “coastal grandmother aesthetic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Strong Wind
description: Patti Varol makes a charming return.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Adam Goldman
title: Secret Service Shoots Armed Man Near the White House
description: President Trump was in Florida at the time of the episode, during which a 27-year-old man held a gun and a confrontation ensued, the agency said.
content: The Secret Service shot a 27-year-old man near the White House early Sunday after an “armed confrontation” with federal officers, the agency said in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino
title: He Was Once a Covert Taliban Operative. Now He’s the Friendly Taxman.
description: Abdul Qahar Ghorbandi, head of Afghanistan’s Taxpayers Services Directorate, has the hard job of raising money in an impoverished country hobbled by international sanctions.
content: He is the Taxman of Kabul, a bearded, black-turbaned Talib with a genial manner and the calculating mind of a computer-savvy accountant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: A Reporter With a Wealth of Knowledge on the Wealthy
description: What do fluctuating egg prices and ultraluxury restaurants have in common? They both fall under one Metro reporter’s beat.
content: As a reporter for The New York Times, Dionne Searcey has, as she put it, covered “a gazillion different things.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Sometimes, You Really Just Need a Strawberry Smoothie
description: And that time is these gray days of early March.
content: Good morning. “Dear Winter,” the sign in front of a local business read, “I’m breaking up with you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Devadanam
title: In ‘Dark Winds,’ Things Are About to Get Even Darker
description: Zahn McClarnon, who plays a Navajo cop in AMC crime drama, talks about the coming third season, which is moodier and more mystical than previous ones.
content: “Dark Winds,” the AMC desert-noir drama centered on a Navajo Tribal Police force in 1970s New Mexico, has been widely acclaimed since its debut in 2022, and viewing numbers have also been solid. An average of 2 million people tuned in for each episode, AMC said, good enough for the second season to rank among the 10 most-watched cable dramas in 2023. Then last year, the series received the well-known Netflix bump after its first two seasons arrived on the service in August, landing in the Top 10 of Nielsen’s overall streaming chart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: The Urgent Supreme Court Case That’s Not Getting Enough Attention
description: The case invites further fragmentation of public education.
content: While the country holds its breath for the Supreme Court’s responses to the Trump administration’s serial depredations, it’s hard to focus on anything else. Nonetheless, a case set for argument next month before the court merits more attention than the little it has received, given its destabilizing potential for public education. The central question is whether a state that allows charter schools as alternatives to traditional public schools, as nearly all states do, must agree to fund those that are explicitly religious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: Kennedy Wants to Cure Chronic Disease. Here’s What He’s Up Against.
description: Ending chronic disease requires major social change.
content: Our health care system has failed patients when it comes to preventing and managing chronic diseases such as diabetes, heart disease and obesity. I see the consequences every day. We tell our patients to diet and exercise when they do not have the time or financial resources to do so. Once a patient has a heart attack or a stroke, our system will deliver excellent care, but then we leave the recovery to beleaguered family members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Katie Glueck and Kellen Browning
title: Ambitious Democrats Have a New Game Plan: Yak It Up About Sports
description: Prominent leaders are flocking to sports radio shows and podcasts, an early sign of how the party is trying to reach apolitical young men who have tilted toward President Trump.
content: “I hate the Packers,” Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota said of his state’s rival football team from Wisconsin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Banker Mark Carney Wins Race to Lead Liberal Party, and Canada
description: The prominent central banker and investor was chosen in a crucial leadership race amid threats from President Trump. He is expected to quickly call a federal election.
content: Amid a generational crisis in Canada’s relationship with the United States, the Liberal Party of Canada on Sunday chose an unelected technocrat with deep experience in financial markets to replace Justin Trudeau as party leader and the country’s prime minister, and to take on President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Michael Crowley
title: Plan to Return Russian Diplomats to U.S. Poses Espionage Risk
description: The Trump administration is negotiating the return of more Russian diplomats to the United States. Some are likely to be spies.
content: As it moves to transform U.S. relations with Russia, the Trump administration is talking with Moscow about readmitting potentially scores of Russian diplomats into the United States after years of expulsions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Colby Smith and Ana Swanson
title: Trump Declines to Rule Out Recession as Tariffs Begin to Bite
description: President Trump said that Americans would be better off in the long run from his tariffs, which he said would prevent the country from being “ripped off.”
content: President Trump declined in an interview aired Sunday to rule out the possibility that his economic policies, including aggressive tariffs against America’s trade partners, would cause a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Collins
title: The Crack of Rifles, Then Silence: What a Firing Squad Execution Was Like
description: One of the three media witnesses to the execution of Brad Sigmon in South Carolina on Friday describes what he saw.
content: I’ve now watched through glass and bars as 11 men were put to death at a South Carolina prison. None of the previous 10 prepared me for watching the firing squad death of Brad Sigmon on Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Chaos at the V.A.: Inside the DOGE Cuts Disrupting the Veterans Agency
description: Clinical trials have been delayed, contracts canceled and support staff fired. With deeper cuts coming, some are warning of potential harms to veterans.
content: At the Veterans Affairs hospital in Pittsburgh, researchers spent months preparing for a clinical trial of a new drug to treat advanced cancers of the mouth, throat and voice box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Monday Briefing: Violence Continues in Syria
description: Plus, reading festivals in India.
content: Syria’s interim president, Ahmed al-Shara, appealed yesterday for calm and unity after violence erupted last week between fighters affiliated with his government and those loyal to the ousted dictator Bashar al-Assad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg and Alexandra E. Petri
title: Plane With 5 Aboard Crashes in Lancaster County, Pa.
description: Those on board were taken to a hospital, officials said, and three of them were transported to a burn center. Radio transmissions indicated the pilot reported an “open door” just before the crash.
content: A small aircraft carrying five people crashed in the parking lot of a retirement community in Lancaster County, Pa., on Sunday afternoon, according to local officials, after the pilot reported there was an “open door,” air traffic transmissions show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Inside the Sean Combs Hotline: The Makings of a Mass Tort
description: From a low-slung building in Montana, employees process sex abuse complaints against the music mogul that have been drawn to them through advertising and a viral hotline.
content: In a room full of cubicles, workers in headsets read from their computer screens, addressing callers who dialed a 1-800 number. They have a script.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Pager and Maggie Haberman
title: The Populist vs. the Billionaire: Bannon, Musk and the Battle Within MAGA
description: President Trump has made clear he wants to keep both men and their allies within his movement, but the tensions are growing.
content: After word leaked out about a clash at the White House where members of President Trump’s cabinet challenged the authority of Elon Musk to reshape their departments, one of the president’s top allies, Stephen K. Bannon, quickly piled on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Romania Bars Ultranationalist Candidate From Presidential Race
description: The country’s electoral commission ruled on Sunday that Calin Georgescu, an outspoken critic of Ukraine and NATO, could not compete in the do-over election.
content: Calin Georgescu, an ultranationalist candidate who won the first round of Romania’s abruptly aborted presidential election last year, has been barred from competing in a do-over vote scheduled for May, sparking a small but violent protest by his supporters in Bucharest, the Romanian capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: When the World’s Fair Came Tumbling Down
description: The Panama-Pacific International Exposition was held in San Francisco in 1915. After it ended, the fair’s temporary structures had to be razed.
content: In 1915, San Francisco held the World’s Fair. The Panama-Pacific International Exposition, as the fair was called, celebrated the Panama Canal, which had opened the previous year, and showcased the recovery and resilience of San Francisco, which had been rocked by a devastating earthquake in 1906.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe and Bea Malsky
title: Tracking Tropical Cyclone Jude
description: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Jude.

author: By Miriam Jordan, Farah Otero-Amad and James Surdam
title: How the Immigration Crackdown Threatens Elderly Care
description: The U.S. relies heavily on immigrant workers to care for its aging population, with nearly 30 percent of direct care workers coming from other countries. As the demand for caregivers grows, President Trump’s immigration crackdown could worsen workforce shortages, driving up wages and making elder care even more expensive for families at a time when America’s elderly population is the highest it has ever been.
content: The U.S. relies heavily on immigrant workers to care for its aging population, with nearly 30 percent of direct care workers coming from other countries. As the demand for caregivers grows, President Trump’s immigration crackdown could worsen workforce shortages, driving up wages and making elder care even more expensive for families at a time when America’s elderly population is the highest it has ever been.
source.name: The New York Times

title: There is a Liberal Answer to Elon Musk
description: Right-wing populism thrives on scarcity. The answer is abundance. But a politics of abundance will work only if Democrats confront where their approach has failed.
content: Right-wing populism thrives on scarcity. The answer is abundance. But a politics of abundance will work only if Democrats confront where their approach has failed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can This Georgia Factory Survive DOGE?
description: Fitzgerald, Ga., wanted to become the hunger-solution capital of the world — until the Trump administration took aim at U.S.A.I.D.
